lines.text: Born a slave, I never was!
It is better to light one candle than to curse the darkness.

[about Genghis Khan]
We will crush this wolf, this thirster after blood, this corrupt defiler of women, this... scavenger!

[the Mongols have come to China]
I think he will let you all become lazy and fat, so we'll never get out.
She is right. Every morning our men will train with their weapons!
I have thought of your lesson, mighty Emperor, and it is true; it is better to light one candle than to curse the darkness. Therefore, I allow you to light this last spectacle!
Perhaps once, in many centuries, does the world produce a man with the power and the will equal to his vision and destiny. Genghis Khan is such a man!

[talking of Ghengis Kahn]
He must not be allowed to leave China; he knows that behind our walls we have grown weak, and can no longer resist invaders.

[on his death chair]
Do not weep for me yet. There will be much time after I am dead.
From here on out, you shall be titled the Genghis Khan!
[crowd cheers]

[about the Caravan Road]
The Shah of Khwarezm imposed a truce. All have sworn to it. All observe it. No warrior is permitted to carry arms here.
Good, then we can take our pick without fighting!
You do not understand, Temujin. A truce was signed!
I did not sign it, the slaves did not sign it.
But...!

[Interrupts]
Will there be women among the slaves?
Yes, lord...
Good. My men have horses and weapons, but no women. How long do you think they will stay without women?
[At Shan]
How long will you?
[Shan smirks]

[addresses Jamuga's troops]
You will now decide whether to join me, or die. I wish there to be no more fighting between the Mongols, so choose now.
[has won the hand of the Emperor's daughter in marriage]
[leads his bride to Bortei]
Show her how to be a proper wife.
It's about time you too, my Lord, had thoughts of sons.
The thoughts I've had in my mind are not for a holy man as you! Give me time.
I come with a message from my master, the great Genghis Khan.
No woman will be taken against her will.
But Lord, that's what women are for! And besides, the best have already been taken!
A wise man does not judge a horse by its saddle markings!

[in his death chair]
Set me so that I can feel the East wind on my face.
The only time that Mongols are joined together is in death.

[about Jamuga]
As long as this man lives, none of his tribe will join with you. They can't! You know their laws. And our laws too.
Killing him would be an act of mercy.
We're not talking of mercy, but of common sense!
If I were free from this yoke, my hands would steal your jackal breath forever!
